sen.j: 煮酛（にもと）は、平安時代中期から室町時代末期にかけて、もっとも上質で高級であった日本酒とされる南都諸白に用いられた製法の一つ。
sen.e: "Ni-moto" was one of the producing methods of "Nanto moro-haku," the sake that kept its reputation of having the highest quality & grade from the middle of the Heian period to the end of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 現代風にいうと生酛系に属する高温糖化法である。
sen.e: In today's words, ni-moto can be described as the high-temperature saccharification method, which falls under "ki-moto" (one of the methods for preparing the starter mash).

sen.j: 酛を、釜に入れて煮ることによって酒母造りを行なうのだが、もちろん高熱で酵母が死んでしまわないように、ぎりぎりの温度で留めて行なわれたことに疑いを容れない。
sen.e: With "moto" (the starter mash) simmered in a pot, the volume of moto was increased, and undoubtedly, simmering must have been done at the very limit temperature lest the yeast should be killed.
sen.cmt: ・「酒母造り」とは「酛を増やすこと」です。
sen.e: By simmering the moto (the starter mash) in a pot, its volume increased, and undoubtedly simmering must have been performed within a very narrow temperature range because the yeast would have been killed if the temperature was too high.

sen.j: 温度計のない時代に、造り手の感覚だけでそれが調節されたことは明らかで、熟練を要した高度な技術であったことがうかがわれる。
sen.e: Since there was no thermometer at that time, it is obvious that the temperature adjustment fully depended on the brewer's sense, and this suggests the method was a high technique which demanded a long experience.
